enrich_metadata.label: San Francisco
enrich_metadata.mention_address: SF, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: San Francisco (/sæn frənˈsɪskoʊ/), officially the City and County of San Francisco, is the cultural, commercial, and financial center of Northern California and the only consolidated city-county in California. San Francisco encompasses a land area of about 46.9 square miles (121 km2) on the northern end of the San Francisco Peninsula, which makes it the smallest county in the state. It has a density of about 18,187 people per square mile (7,022 people per km2), making it the most densely settled large city (population greater than 200,000) in the state of California and the second-most densely populated major city in the United States after New York City. San Francisco is the fourth-most populous city in California, after Los Angeles, San Diego and San Jose, and the 13th-most populous city in the United States—with a Census-estimated 2014 population of 852,469. The city and its surrounding areas are known as the San Francisco Bay Area, and are a part of the larger OMB designated San Jose-San Francisco-Oakland combined statistical area, the fifth most populous in the nation with an estimated population of 8.6 million. San Francisco (Spanish for Saint Francis) was founded on June 29, 1776, when colonists from Spain established Presidio of San Francisco at the Golden Gate and Mission San Francisco de Asís named for St. Francis of Assisi a few miles away. The California Gold Rush of 1849 brought rapid growth, making it the largest city on the West Coast at the time. San Francisco became a consolidated city-county in 1856.After three-quarters of the city was destroyed by the 1906 earthquake and fire, San Francisco was quickly rebuilt, hosting the Panama-Pacific International Exposition nine years later. In World War II, San Francisco was the port of embarkation for service members shipping out to the Pacific Theater. After the war, the confluence of returning servicemen, massive immigration, liberalizing attitudes, along with the rise of the "hippie" counterculture, the Sexual Revolution, the Peace Movement growing from opposition to United States involvement in the Vietnam War, and other factors led to the Summer of Love and the gay rights movement, cementing San Francisco as a center of liberal activism in the United States. Politically, the city votes strongly along liberal Democratic Party lines. San Francisco is a popular tourist destination, known for its cool summers, fog, steep rolling hills, eclectic mix of architecture, and landmarks including the Golden Gate Bridge, cable cars, the former Alcatraz Federal Penitentiary, Fisherman's Wharf, and its Chinatown district. San Francisco is also the headquarters of five major banking institutions and various other companies such as Levi Strauss & Co., Gap Inc., Salesforce.com, Dropbox, Reddit, Square, Inc., Dolby, Airbnb, Weebly, Pacific Gas and Electric Company, Yelp, Pinterest, Twitter, Uber, Mozilla, Wikimedia Foundation, and Craigslist. It has several nicknames, including "The City by the Bay", "Fog City", "San Fran", and "Frisco", as well as older ones like "The City that Knows How", "Baghdad by the Bay", and "The Paris of the West". As of 2015, San Francisco was ranked high on world livability rankings.

enrich_metadata.label: Oakland, California
enrich_metadata.mention_address: Oakland, Alameda County, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: Oakland /ˈoʊklənd/ is a major West Coast port city in the U.S. state of California. Oakland is the third largest city in the San Francisco Bay Area, the eighth-largest city in California, and the 45th-largest city in the U.S. with a population of 413,775 as of 2014. It serves as a trade center for the San Francisco Bay Area; its Port of Oakland is the busiest port for San Francisco Bay, all of Northern California, and fifth busiest in the United States. Incorporated in 1852, Oakland is the county seat of Alameda County. It is also the principal city of the Bay Area Region known as the East Bay. The city is situated directly across the bay, six miles (9.7 km) east of San Francisco. Oakland's territory covers what was once a mosaic of coastal terrace prairie, oak woodland, and north coastal scrub. Its land served as a rich resource when its hillside oak and redwood timber were logged to build San Francisco, and Oakland's fertile flatland soils helped it become a prolific agricultural region. In the late 1860s, Oakland was selected as the western terminal of the Transcontinental Railroad. Following the 1906 San Francisco earthquake, many San Franciscans relocated to Oakland, enlarging the city's population, increasing its housing stock and improving its infrastructure. It continued to grow in the 20th century with its busy port, shipyards, and a thriving automobile manufacturing industry. Oakland is known for its sustainability practices, including a top ranking for usage of electricity from renewable resources. Oakland is also known for its history of political activism, as well as its professional sports franchises and major corporations, which include health care, dot-com companies and manufacturers of household products. In addition, thanks to a steady influx of immigrants during the 20th century, along with thousands of African-American war-industry workers who relocated from the Deep South during the 1940s, Oakland is one of the most ethnically diverse major cities in the country.
enrich_metadata.subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Oakland,_California

The city is located in the North Bay region of the San Francisco Bay Area. As of the 2010 census the city's population is 57,713.

enrich_metadata.label: San Juan Capistrano, California
enrich_metadata.mention_address: San Juan Capistrano, Orange County, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: San Juan Capistrano (/sæn ˌwɑːn kæpᵻˈstrɑːnoʊ/; [saŋ ˈxwaŋ kapisˈtɾano]) is a city in Orange County, California, United States. The current OMB metropolitan designation for San Juan Capistrano and the Orange County Area is "Santa Ana-Anaheim-Irvine, CA." The population was 34,593 at the 2010 census, up from 33,826 at the 2000 census. The city was created around Mission San Juan Capistrano, and many of the homes and strip malls resemble the Spanish architecture that composes the building. It is home to the widest variety of homes in Orange County, including those built prior to 1900 in its central district (some being adobes from the 18th century). San Juan Capistrano formerly hosted a population of cliff swallows that migrate each year from Argentina to the Mission San Juan Capistrano.
enrich_metadata.subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/San_Juan_Capistrano,_California
enrich_metadata.comment: San Juan Capistrano (/sæn ˌwɑːn kæpᵻˈstrɑːnoʊ/; [saŋ ˈxwaŋ kapisˈtɾano]) is a city in Orange County, California, United States. The current OMB metropolitan designation for San Juan Capistrano and the Orange County Area is "Santa Ana-Anaheim-Irvine, CA." The population was 34,593 at the 2010 census, up from 33,826 at the 2000 census. The city was created around Mission San Juan Capistrano, and many of the homes and strip malls resemble the Spanish architecture that composes the building. It is home to the widest variety of homes in Orange County, including those built prior to 1900 in its central district (some being adobes from the 18th century). San Juan Capistrano formerly hosted a population of cliff swallows that migrate each year from Argentina to the Mission San Juan Capistrano.

enrich_metadata.label: Ferndale, California
enrich_metadata.mention_address: Ferndale, Humboldt County, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: Ferndale is a city in Humboldt County, California, United States. Its population was 1,371 at the 2010 census, down from 1,382 at the 2000 census. The city contains dozens of well-preserved Victorian storefronts and homes. Ferndale is the northern gateway to California's Lost Coast and the city, which is sited on the edge of a wide plain near the mouth of the Eel River, is also located near the extensive preserves of Coast Redwood forests.
enrich_metadata.subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Ferndale,_California
enrich_metadata.comment: Ferndale is a city in Humboldt County, California, United States. Its population was 1,371 at the 2010 census, down from 1,382 at the 2000 census. Ferndale is the northern gateway to California's Lost Coast and the city, which is sited on the edge of a wide plain near the mouth of the Eel River, is also located near the extensive preserves of Coast Redwood forests.

enrich_metadata.label: Aliso Viejo, California
enrich_metadata.abstract: Aliso Viejo is a city in the San Joaquin Hills of southern Orange County, California. It had a population of 47,823 as of the 2010 census, up from 40,166 as of the 2000 census. It became Orange County's 34th city on July 1, 2001, the only city in Orange County to be incorporated since 2000. It is bordered by the cities of Laguna Beach on the west and southwest, Laguna Hills on the east, Laguna Niguel on the southeast, and Laguna Woods on the north.

It became Orange County's 34th city on July 1, 2001, the only city in Orange County to be incorporated since 2000. It is bordered by the cities of Laguna Beach on the west and southwest, Laguna Hills on the east, Laguna Niguel on the southeast, and Laguna Woods on the north.

enrich_metadata.label: Dublin, California
enrich_metadata.abstract: Dublin (formerly, Amador and Dougherty's Station) is a suburban city of the East (San Francisco) Bay region of Alameda County, California, United States. Located along the north side of Interstate 580 at the intersection with Interstate 680, roughly 10 miles (16 km) east of Hayward, 6 miles (9.7 km) west of Livermore, directly north of Pleasanton, and 35 miles (56 km) north of San Jose, it was named after the city of Dublin in Ireland.[citation needed] The nearest major city is Oakland, approximately 25 miles (40 km) to the west-northwest on Interstate 580. Dublin is the second fastest-growing city in the state of California, behind only Santa Clarita. The population was 46,063 (2010 census), and the 2013 estimate at 49,890. It is forecast that by 2030, the population will grow to about 75,900.[citation needed] Dublin is home to the headquarters of Sybase, Inc, now part of SAP SE, Tria Beauty, Medley Health and Arlen Ness.

enrich_metadata.label: Dana Point, California
enrich_metadata.mention_address: Dana Point, Orange County, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: Dana Point is a city located in southern Orange County, California. The population was 33,351 at the 2010 census. It has one of the few harbors along the Orange County coast, and with ready access via State Route 1, it is a popular local destination for surfing. The city was named after the headland of Dana Point, which was in turn named after Richard Henry Dana, Jr., author of Two Years Before the Mast, which included a description of the area. Dana described the locale, including neighboring San Juan Capistrano, as "the only romantic spot on the coast". Although Dana described the anchorage as poor, it is now a developed harbor and contains a replica of his ship, the Pilgrim. The Pilgrim is used as a classroom by the Ocean Institute, which is located at the harbor. This area is designated California Historical Landmark #189.

enrich_metadata.label: San Diego
enrich_metadata.abstract: San Diego /ˌsæn diːˈeɪɡoʊ/ (Spanish for "Saint Didacus") is a major city in California, on the coast of the Pacific Ocean in Southern California, approximately 120 miles (190 km) south of Los Angeles and immediately adjacent to the border with Mexico. With an estimated population of 1,381,069 as of July 1, 2014, San Diego is the eighth-largest city in the United States and second-largest in California. San Diego is the birthplace of California and is known for its mild year-round climate, natural deep-water harbor, extensive beaches, long association with the U.S. Navy, and recent emergence as a healthcare and biotechnology development center. Historically home to the Kumeyaay people, San Diego was the first site visited by Europeans on what is now the West Coast of the United States. Upon landing in San Diego Bay in 1542, Juan Rodríguez Cabrillo claimed the entire area for Spain, forming the basis for the settlement of Alta California 200 years later. The Presidio and Mission of San Diego, founded in 1769, formed the first European settlement in what is now California. In 1821, San Diego became part of newly independent Mexico, and in 1850, became part of the United States following the Mexican–American War and the admission of California to the union. The city is the seat of San Diego County and is the economic center of the region as well as the San Diego–Tijuana metropolitan area. San Diego's main economic engines are military and defense-related activities, tourism, international trade, and manufacturing. The presence of the University of California, San Diego (UCSD), with the affiliated UCSD Medical Center, has helped make the area a center of research in biotechnology.

attraction_reviewComments: The Redwood Highway is the perfect place to enjoy scenic views of the coastline, the rivers, forests and mountains.
Even though its only 31 miles long it will take u several ours to drive it because u pull off the road to see the huge trees every 10 feet it seems like! and there r hiking trails... read more
No matter how many times you see these amazing trees in books/photos/images it still doesn't prepare you for the real thing and seeing them in the flesh. Driving through them was... read more
Take the time to drive and stop along the Avenue of the Giants. Amazing! Take a few hours to really explore. Bring food along as places to eat are very limited!
Had a great time driving through the redwood forest. Stopped at one of the trailheads and enjoyed a 5 mile walk. So many things to see that I could have spent the whole day... read more
Take this trip... You will love it! It is on the way, and well worth it. Take the Avenue of the Giants, stop in the park and have a picnic lunch among the redwoods.
Drove through the Redwood Highway enroute to Portland, Oregon. Saw some of the largest trees I have ever seen in my life. Truly God's creations!
Travelling north from the Bay Area to Humboldt State University. Traffic can be heavy at times and slow in places, but relax and enjoy the scenery.
From Eureka north to Crescent City, winding road along the coast and through magnificent stand of redwoods. At sunset, sun filters through the trees creating striations of light... read more
This wasn't a hard drive.... it was relaxing with something to observe around every corner!!! So unique!!! The Redwood trees were absolutely beautiful!!!! Wildlife was in... read more
Traveled here while visiting northern California and Oregon. Were amazed at the beauty of the redwoods and the surrounding mountains.
Very few times in life you have the opportunity to enjoy a scenic drive like this... Amazing trees higher than a skyscraper. Wonderful... A must go at least once in a life.
Stunning experience to drive from San Fran to Eureka with a lot of time spent on the Avenue of the Giants. Recommend Founders Grove, Humboldt Park Visitor Center and driving... read more
We experienced all 3. Husband says Trees of Mystery has changed little, except for the included, optional gondola ride. Took the off road that indicated elk might be seen, and, o... read more
Traveled Avenue of the Giants both ways and was blown away by how big the trees are. Very peaceful experience. Very few cars so you can take your time and pull over whenever you... read more
It was great to bring the kids to this beautiful area. Both my wife and I did it with our families as kids. Trees of mystery and many view points to pull off 101 and take in.
It is a most wonderful and breath taking experience. The trees are awesome in size and beauty. Suggest you take it slow and easy. There are many stops along the way and you can... read more
Views are spectacular and there are so many inviting places to stop and hike. Also plan time to spend at the Redwoods National Forest where the enormous trees are dense and the... read more
This is a beautiful area of the country. The redwoods are magnificent. Not to be missed if you are traveling North.
Very pretty drive through the tall and shady avenues-very pleasing and tranquil.Some trees are right on the roadside so care has to be taken
I love the redwood highway. Amazing scenery and lots of places to pull over for vistas or picnics. I definitely recommend taking the Avenue of The Giants road. Beautiful
We enjoyed stopping at every little stop for pictures. Trees are wonderful. The kids couldn't believe how tall they were. So glad to revisit this place with the family.
My wife and I came to California to see the redwoods and this is the highway you need to travel. All of the state and National Parks are easily accessible from this highway... read more
The drive on the new 101 and the old 101 are remarkably different, but both spectacular. Stop at the Grandfather, one of the oldest Redwoods, 1200 years old. It is huge, but not... read more
It gets you where you need to go quickly and with great views at times. Be sure to take the old freeway known as Avenue of the Giants if you want to see old growth redwood trees.
While it is a bit south of Eureka (about 25 miles) it is so well worth the drive, absolutely beautiful.
Just keep in mind that this is not a destination, but a road to your destination(s). That said, it's a beautiful road also know as Hwy 101... so while you go through ancient... read more
Drove down Avenue of the Giants. Lots of giant trees to see. We stopped at Lady Bird Johnson Grove it was the best. We had been on a trail at Jedidah Smith State Park which was... read more
I was so humbled and hopeful that my generation and all future generations will have the opportunity to see and preserve this national natural treasure
We were not sure what to expect because we never saw such big beautiful trees. The drive is very scenic and worth the drive. I wish the drive was a bit longer but worth the... read more
the redwoods, the fog, the strength of nature: so humbling to view and be lost in. the scenery is breathtaking and time to walk in the forest is ivigorating, relaaxing, and a... read more
If you are heading up I5 and have the time to jump over to 101 instead, do it. If you are looking for an amazing drive in the US, don't miss this one. Most of the Redwoods... read more
Patches of redwoods along the way. You usually need to take an exit to see more redwood trees. The drive is beautiful nonetheless. It is quite windy and you drive through many... read more
We love driving through this area. The highway itself is surrounded by a beautiful, amazingly tall forrest of redwoods. There are quite a few little gift shops and cute food... read more
One of the best roadtrips in the USA.Gorgeous view with the smell of redwoods. Lots of places for camping and rustic gift shops abound. Stop anywhere for hiking trails.
If you ever been this area, just drive on Redwood highway already make you feel happy! I drove back and forth to see those parks and beaches, always feeling great on my way... read more
We decided to go down from Oregon to the Redwoods. What we found on the Avenue of the Giants were the two out of three of the drive-thru trees. Make sure you have a car or truck... read more
First time on the northern California coast on a family vacation to the Oregon coast. Views are beautiful.
You simply cannot drive down 101 and not get off to drive this road. The views are amazing. The size of the Redwood trees, the beauty of the trees and the ferns and the... read more
Only problem is that they are constantly working on this highway and the travel is slow and the driver has to pay too much attention to the road, but get out and see this wonder.
What a treasure! Even though there was a fire in the state park, we were able to do a few short hikes among the Redwoods. So interesting and beautiful! Be sure to stop and walk... read more
Completely astonishing & absolutely breathtaking - you have to see it to believe how giant these trees are.
The lesser known part of US Highway 101. This part gets more and more spectacular you drive north. Try do drive in the early hours of the date, as you may catch the great foggy... read more
The Redwoods are amazing.Some of them are so old they deserve a stop and photo opportunity. That said, watch out for cars stopped on the shoulders and people trying to cross to... read more
Coming out of the Redwoods to an ocean crashing against the rocks is an amazing sight. Highway 1 along the Northern CA coast is awesome. Especially love between Eureka and... read more
The only way out of Eureka is on 101 or 199. 101 follows the coast going North to and through Oregon. Love the speed limit of 55 in Oregon - perfect for seeing the sights and... read more
Was trying to get to Washington but avoiding the Siskeyou Pass (and all of the big rigs). What a lovely drive throughout California and into Southern Oregon. I was surprised how... read more
This past weekend we took 2 guests through the Avenue of the Giants and did the walk through Founders' Grove. It didn't faze them that it was pouring rain, or keep them from... read more
So beautiful one of the few places I still get out and take pictures ... so many diff places to explore and cute shops ..

enrich_metadata.label: Monrovia, California
enrich_metadata.abstract: Monrovia is a city located in the foothills of the San Gabriel Mountains in the San Gabriel Valley of Los Angeles County, California, United States. The population was 36,590 at the 2010 census, down from 36,929 in 2000. Monrovia has been used for filming TV shows, movies and commercials.

enrich_metadata.abstract: Sunnyvale (/ˈsʌniveɪl/ or /ˈsʌnivəl/) is a city located in Santa Clara County, California. As of the 2010 United States Census, the population was 140,095. The city is one of the major cities that make up Silicon Valley. It is the seventh most populous city in the San Francisco Bay Area. Sunnyvale is bordered by portions of San Jose to the north, Moffett Federal Airfield to the northwest, Mountain View to the west, Los Altos to the southwest, Cupertino to the south, and Santa Clara to the east. It lies along the historic El Camino Real and Highway 101. As part of California's high-tech area known as Silicon Valley, companies such as Juniper Networks, Fortinet, Advanced Micro Devices, NetApp, Spansion, Yahoo!, AppliedMicro and Ariba are headquartered there. Sunnyvale is also home to several aerospace/defense companies; Lockheed Martin has a major facility in Sunnyvale, and Honeywell, Northrop Grumman Electronic Systems - Marine Systems (formerly Joshua Hendy Iron Works), Finisar, and Spirent also have offices in Sunnyvale. Sunnyvale was also the home to Onizuka Air Force Station, often referred to as "the Blue Cube" due to the color and shape of its windowless main building. The facility, previously known as Sunnyvale Air Force Station, was named for the deceased Space Shuttle Challenger astronaut Ellison Onizuka. It served as an artificial satellite control facility of the United States armed forces until August 2010 and has since been decommissioned and demolished. Sunnyvale is one of the few U.S. cities to have a single unified Department of Public Safety, where all personnel are trained as firefighters, police officers, and EMTs, so they can respond to an emergency in any of the three roles. Library services for the city are provided by the Sunnyvale Public Library, located at the Sunnyvale Civic Center.

enrich_metadata.mention_address: Riverside, Riverside County, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: Riverside is a city in Riverside County, California, United States, located in the Inland Empire metropolitan area. Riverside is the county seat of the eponymous county and named for its location beside the Santa Ana River. It is the most populous city in the Inland Empire as well as Riverside County, and is located approximately 60 miles (97 km) east of Los Angeles. It is also part of the Greater Los Angeles area. Riverside is the 59th most populous city in the United States and 12th most populous city in California. As of the 2010 Census, Riverside had a population of 303,871. Riverside was founded in the early 1870s and is the birthplace of the California citrus industry as well as home of the Mission Inn, the largest Mission Revival Style building in the United States. It is also home to the Riverside National Cemetery. The University of California, Riverside, is located in the northeastern part of the city. The university also hosts the Riverside Sports Complex. Other attractions in Riverside include the Fox Performing Arts Center, Riverside Metropolitan Museum, which houses exhibits and artifacts of local history, the California Museum of Photography, the California Citrus State Historic Park, and the Parent Washington Navel Orange Tree, the last of the two original navel orange trees in California.

enrich_metadata.mention_address: Burbank, Los Angeles County, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: Burbank is a city in Los Angeles County in Southern California, United States, 12 miles (19 km) northwest of downtown Los Angeles. The population at the 2010 census was 103,340. Billed as the "Media Capital of the World" and only a few miles northeast of Hollywood, numerous media and entertainment companies are headquartered or have significant production facilities in Burbank, including The Walt Disney Company, Warner Bros. Entertainment, ABC Studios, ABC Family, Marvel Studios, Nickelodeon, NBC, and Insomniac Games. The city is also home to Bob Hope Airport. Burbank also holds a special place in aerospace history since Lockheed's Skunk Works in Burbank produced some of the most secret and technologically advanced airplanes, including the U-2 spy planes that uncovered the Soviet Union missile components in Cuba. Burbank consists of two distinct areas: a downtown, in the foothills of the Verdugo Mountains, and flatlands, at the east end of the San Fernando Valley. At one time, it was referred to as "Beautiful Downtown Burbank" on Laugh-In and The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson. The city was named after David Burbank, a New Hampshire-born dentist and entrepreneur.
enrich_metadata.subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Burbank,_California

attraction_reviewComments: It is hard to explain the absolute majestic grandeur (can't think of better terms to use) of this drive down through gigantic redwood trees. You feel like you have somehow... read more
I have hiked in many places before, but hiking through the redwoods at Prairie Creek was fabulous--the trail was cushiony because of plant materials on the trail, and we had the... read more
We enjoyed this park-it was our 2nd favorite (first being Humboldt Redwoods State Park) of our N CA trip. Its main attraction for us was the viewing of the Roosevelt Elk in their... read more
The mind boggles at the sight of these majestic trees, some hundreds of years old reaching up to about 300 feet. One is awestruck by the sheer size and numbers.
This was a 3.6 mile loop trail through a quiet section of Prairie Creek Redwoods State Park. It is located off of the Drury Scenic Parkway. It starts out quite level and then... read more
We took the coastal road and were on some of the neatest stretches, high bluffs, low spots by the ocean, gravel roads and finished roads, some narrow, but all nice to travel on... read more
The redwoods are Gorgeous. Take the time to drive the scenic byway. You'll be glad you did. We visited in July, the peak season and although there were lots of visitors we never... read more
First, big compliment to the staff of the visitor center. They had gave great information and directions....so helpful! I just wanted to see the redwoods by driving through... read more
Prairie Creek is an outstanding family vacation spot. We camp in this park every summer. The junior ranger programs are fantastic. Our kids grew up with these programs and still... read more
Even in the rain it's a gorgeous. Came here through gold bluffs beach and did fern canyon. It was amazing, fern canyon is where the lost world was filmed, some of it anyways. From... read more
Beautiful park, connected to the National park. Miles of trails. Hike a few yards or a whole day. Massive old growth redwoods everywhere.
We traveled through Prairie Woods as part of a day long trip to see the redwood forests. The Drury road was very pleasant and not too crowded. We visited Big Tree at the Big... read more
The beautiful drive makes it tempting to just cruise along the peaceful road, but don't you dare miss out. Park that puppy and get out and walk. It's a whole different experience... read more
My husband and I were referred to this park by a local friend. She knows we are avid hikers and outdoor enthusiasts, and this was her first pick for us. It was a much-needed... read more
There's no reason anyone driving down the coast through the redwoods should not stop somewhere along this path and go for a hike in these woods. There's nothing like it on Earth... read more
This has to be one of the most beautiful state parks in California. We drove out dirt Davidson Rd to Gold Bluffs Beach. No four wheel drive needed, just good sense. We walked into... read more
We enjoyed our hikes and drive through Prairie Creek Redwoods State Park. Hikes into the deep old growth forests and out along the beach, went throughout the park. Ancient... read more
This is a great drive. It was recommended for us as a great alternative to the National Park if you want to see the redwoods close without hiking. Perfect if you are not into the... read more
We loved all the redwoods we saw but the scenic parkway was especially nice. It was a paved road and you could go at your own speed. The man in the visitor center was especially... read more
This park was beautiful. The views of the ocean, the beach, the trees, fern canyon, and the elk! I recommend checking it out.
This is one of the many places to see an old growth redwood stand, or a dozen of them. There are trails along the road, and going out towards the beach. They range from very... read more
If your time is limited, this is the redwood park you should visit. Don't waste your time with Redwood National Park. The scenery here is better with a lot more old growth. Hiking... read more
